_header: The Mass is of so high dignity
Subjects: oaths, criticism of; mass; carols, of religious counsel
_description: Against swearing by the Mass — six quatrains (aaaa) and burden (bb): ‘Y concell yow both more and lasse / Beware of swerynge by the masse’

OxfBal354.First Lines:
The masse is of so high dignyteeÞat no thyng to it
                    comprehendid may be…
OxfBal354.Last Lines:
…Þat whan þe erth hath couered thy faceThy sowle in
                    hevyn may haue a placeExplicit
OxfBal354.Note: Six stanzas, including one not in Cambridge UK,  Trinity College O.9.38 (1450).
OxfBal354.Facsimiles:
Early Manuscripts at Oxford University: Facsimile
                    of Oxford, Balliol MS 354.
         (http://image.ox.ac.uk/show?collection=balliol&manuscript=ms354).

         26 (1903): 94-285: 263-4.
Dyboski,  R.,

             Songs, Carols and Other Miscellaneous Poems from Balliol MS. 354,

EETS

CamTCC1450.First Lines:
The masse ys of suwch dygnyteNothyng to hyt comprysyd may
                    be…
CamTCC1450.Last Lines:
…ffor when erth hath coueryde thy faceThen all that ys turnyd
                    as hyt wasse
CamTCC1450.Editions:
Greene,  Richard Leighton. 
             The Early English Carols.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon,
            1977: 226-7; 1977, 201-2.
